due to overall huge change (and this being just a part of a bigger change) I was not really trying to improve or rework the them as such. That would also make review even more complex.
wrt _to_munch: sadly here we need the shade-like functionality, since in the cloud layer we once gave contract to return munch object, and now we struggle.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I don't see where this problem was and where it got fixed. It just looks like you moved the if-config-true-validate check from the agent to PXEBoot.validate(). Or maybe that's what this means, that PXEBoot.validate() wasn't being called (even though it now is called but does nothing if the config is true).

The key there is that was impacting all drivers for essentially a setting that was only valid for the PXE driver. 

Think about this: if half my nodes use the pxe driver, and the other half use some other driver (lets say, something with vmedia support like iLO), we skipped validate in *both* cases for a setting that was only supposed to modify pxe booting. By limiting the scope we make it more correct for mixed use cases.

Words are hard :) I probably wouldn't have mentioned this at all. It *could* have been a problem if we used the agent with some other boot interface. But that's ok, now that you've explained what you meant. Thx.
s/behavior/behaviour
Yeah, both spellings should be fine.
Leaving this as US english, IMO both British and English spellings are acceptable.
"Behavior" is the correct spelling in US English - do we have a preferred English dialect for commit messages etc?
/s/behaviors/behaviours
See above, this is US English spelling. http://www.dictionary.com/browse/behavior?s=t

ironic/drivers/modules/agent.py.message: Moving this check into the pxe driver directly. The agent driver shouldn't need to act based on another drivers' config option.
This also changes behavior for ilo/irmc boot interfaces.

This is somewhat intentional. CONF.agent.manage_agent_boot should never have disabled validate across the board. I see this as a bugfix change, but am welcome to hear other arguments if you still disagree :).

I added a line to the releasenotes highlighting this fix as well.
ditto, does the same problem exists for virtual media, with setting boot device to cdrom?

Explicitly the reason I'm moving this to a pxe setting instead of an agent setting is that we can't/shouldn't determine what boot device to set and similar things from the deploy interface. It has to be managed by the boot interface. This means it'll be the boot drivers' responsibility, in prepare_ramdisk(), to set whatever boot device they need.

ironic/drivers/modules/deploy_utils.py.message: What if manage_boot is false AND I'm booting the agent using virtual media? In this case, you'd break me because you'd force me to PXE instead of booting off vmedia.
`manage_boot` is realistically "manage tftp". Why don't we always call prepare_ramdisk, pass in this option, and let prepare_ramdisk do things conditionally?

I like Jim's idea. We should switch the boot method in prepare_ramdisk since that comes from the driver boot interface, so if it's PXE prepare_ramdisk we should always PXE boot. That will solve the problem with agent+iLO as well.
agent + iLO driver supports virtual media. I'd suggest looking to see how they handle some of these cases there.
Is there an existing case in ironic where someone would want to do this? If so we can make this a config option.

configuration.yaml.message: Where is this date coming from?  I don't think it is super important but just can't figure out where you got it from. :-)
ah this seems it is leaving victoria contribution. these dates should cover the victoria and wallaby cycle contributions.

these dates falls before the R6 release [1] and as per TC charter election needs to be held between R6 - R4. We need to shift it little further, may be 2021-03-08 to 2021-03-15

"The election is held no earlier than 6 weeks and no later than 4 weeks prior to each cycle final release date (between ‘R-6’ and ‘R-4’ week),"

[1] https://releases.openstack.org/wallaby/schedule.html
According to https://releases.openstack.org/ Ussuri was released 2020-05-13 so you have the Victoria cycle starting 5 days after the previous release. Is that expected?

yeah, start of any cycle is technically right after the previous release date as contribution of Victoria started right after the Ussuri release (even before for some repo where Victoria branch was cut but Ussuri end date is good standard time to count the Victoria contribution)
I went with the date at the top of the Victoria release schedule, I think, but its fixed now in the next patchset.

we need to have the Campaigning before election starts, Campaigning during election is little confusing and not aligned with the goal of Campaigning.

How about the below dates which match as per the TC charter also and have separate time for Campaigning but with less days.

  - name: TC Nominations
    start: 2021-03-02T23:45
    end: 2021-03-09T23:45
  - name: PTL Nominations
    start: 2021-03-02T23:45
    end: 2021-03-9T23:45
  - name: TC Campaigning
    start: 2021-03-9T23:45
    end: 2021-03-11T23:45
  - name: TC Election
    start: 2021-03-12T23:45
    end: 2021-03-19T23:45
  - name: PTL Election
    start: 2021-03-12T23:45
    end: 2021-03-19T23:45

I honestly think that campaigning can start as soon as nominations open (and continue to run during polling since it often does anyway), but if we feel like there need to be dedicated days for it, I am fine with this setup.

Looking back at the previous elections, we've been consistently picking the timeframe start as the last day of RC1 week for the previous cycle, which is what the setup_election_config.py script does. That would be 2020-04-24 this time (end of Ussuri RC1 week).

For the timeframe end date, the setup_election_config.py script picks the scheduled release date for the cycle *or* the email_deadline deadline if that's sooner than the release. It doesn't make sense to have the end after the email_deadline (just before the end of nominations) since you could be generating electoral rolls any time after that and so can't guarantee you'll be counting contributions past that point anyway.

Per my comment on the previous patchset, the timeframe end would be the same as email_deadline, so 2021-03-08. You could generate electoral rolls as early as the email_deadline date, and if so it would be hard to count contributions which occurred after you obtained the list of contributors. In fact, this is saying people are eligible to vote in the election if they contribute more than a month after the election has ended.

neutron/ipam/requests.py.message: Wasn't this validated before? This relates to the case when user specifies both subnet CIDR and gateway IP, right?

nitty nit:
why not

    netaddr.IPNetwork("%s/%s" % (gateway_ip, prefixlen))

I think this validation should be done at plugin level for consistency with non-subnetpool case: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/90309cf6e2f3ed5ae6d5f4cca3c5351c2ac67a13/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L853 - like in 'else' block of this 'if': https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/90309cf6e2f3ed5ae6d5f4cca3c5351c2ac67a13/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L837

What do you think?

I agree that subnet request validation should be the responsibility of IPAM backend.
However my concern is that cidr <-> gateway_ip is quite a generic check and it's weird to have it at different levels, ideally it should be done once in the code (or at least at same level).

Do you mean we should move the check from https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/90309cf6e2f3ed5ae6d5f4cca3c5351c2ac67a13/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L853 - to the IPAM level?

I think just the opposite: the validation should be done by the particular IPAM SubnetRequest class used. This subclass (SpecificSubnetRequest, AnySubnetRequest) should have the logic to allow or reject the subnet creation. If we implemented a IPAM pluggable backend to handle everything related to subnets, IPs, pools, etc., why are we checking all this [1] in the plugin?

The IPAM backend is in charge of creating the needed SubnetRequest subclass instance, depending on the network and subnet attributes passed. There [2] is where part of those checks should be done or when the request is executed.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/90309cf6e2f3ed5ae6d5f4cca3c5351c2ac67a13/neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py#L821-L853
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/1994fbb8f909178dd8dfc45efd880429b5257e4c/neutron/db/ipam_pluggable_backend.py#L588

Yes, we should move those checks to the IPAM, that's why we implemented it. Nothing related to IPs, cidrs, subnets or pools should be handled by the plugin.

But, of course, this should be done in a patch refactoring this section, not the present one.

heat/policies/base.py.message:
This is a naive question, but is this to prevent the users heat creates from turning around the creating things in heat?

For example, if a heat user account is compromised, this prevents that compromised account from mucking with resources via heat?

No it's for heat_stack_user which can only use a some APIs like signaling,

For any resources that require a user, the Orchestration service creates the user in the stack domain project. The stack domain project is associated with the Orchestration stack in the Orchestration database, but is separate and unrelated (from an authentication perspective) to the stack owners project. The users who are created in the stack domain are still assigned the heat_stack_user role, so the API surface they can access is limited.
Probably a question for Lance, how should an admin project interact with secure-rbac? Depending on the answer maybe this rule can be deprecated?

Leaving as it was impacts the whole project as there are quite a few places that uses the context.is_admin to check permissions. Someone with the new system_admin priviledges and without this legacy is_admin would not be able to do all that an admin can do now. We have to change all those tests for sure, but changing all that and above all testing all that would be a better effort for the the next cycle as it would make us miss the deadline.

This change gives a huge benefit of letting it keep working and with minimal impact.

Good question. The is_admin_project terminology and infrastructure in existing policies and context objects is being replaced with system scope.

The is_admin_project approach was a way to flag users with elevated privilege by denoting a special construct from keystone (e.g., if you have a role assignment on this special project, you get access to do administrative things in the deployment).

We had a session with operators at a summit/PTG sometime early 2017 and there was resistance to 1.) overloading projects for deployment-level resource protection 2.) the manageability of the approach (e.g., what happens if the admin project is accidentally nuked? should we be keeping code in keystone to ensure that doesn't happen?)

Those discussions led to system-scope, default roles, and common personas.

This check can likely be deprecated and removed if everything that's using it is moved to formal system personas.
Should not we leave the rule as is and not change till we start using the new rules and system scope?

Yeah I agree with Rabi that this is not yet the patch to add this. So I'm removing this and I created a WIP patch in this chain with all the deprecated policies removed and worked this code into that. that patch will be the one that will be a turnkey to the new policies.

Also in looking at that I think that we should keep the project_admin role for now, because it is a middle ground between system admin and project member that makes sense for heat. Any thoughts?

Do you mean keep the `context_is_admin` rule? If so, I think that's fine. You can register it as a default policy even if nothing uses it. We can deprecate it for removal once we're sure we migrated everything to a new persona (e.g., system admin).

If places in heat are keying off of is_admin_project or is_admin to evaluate things inline, like this:

  # API code 
  if context.is_admin_project:
      # do something specifically for admins
  else:
      # non-administrative code would go here

then you can replace them with something like this:

  if context.system_scope == 'all' and 'admin' in context.roles:
      # do something specifically for admins

Or we can try and write an adapter in heat's context object that understands both cases and heat call that?

To be clear, I'm not saying we should rip context_is_admin out now. But if every policy using rule:context_is_admin is effectively moved to use a formal system-specific persona, then we can probably deprecated it and stage it for removal.
This patch is just to add new rules but fallback to use the deprecated rules. So I don't understand the above explanation unless I miss something.
Why do we've to change this old rule? PROJECT_ADMIN is not correct here. It's admin user in admin project is what it's earlier (current SYSTEM_ADMIN).
Isn't SYSTEM_ADMIN has the READER role as well?
Can we remove this change from here? We should not be changing old rules which works.

OK, I think we could have changed[1] to allow SYSTEM_ADMIN rather than changing this old rule. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/common/policy.py#L109-L120

If we don't change this the system_admin will not be able to do any admin stuff. all the admin stuff is controlled by this check. Changing here makes it work and is better in my opinion than changing a lot of other calls. I'm not talking about the policy enforcer decorator there's a bunch of code in other places and inside the calls that check the is_admin that is set up by this rule.

swift/container/sharder.py.message: this is only called from one site fo not really necessary
This is eligibility to be... included in the compactible sequence? And that's why we have to allow sr.name==own_sr.name, is that right?

I think shard_range.name == own_shard_range.name is redundant.

Historically, the list of shard ranges previously had own_sr appended so that it could be an acceptor, and its state would be SHARDED, so a special case was needed to consider own_sr for a sequence. That special case became part of is_eligible() in this patch. But looking back at the patch that added 'compact' command, that patched stopped appending own_sr to the list and dealt with the special case later:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/765623/16/swift/container/sharder.py#198:

So we no longer expect own_sr to be in the list that is searched for compactible sequences.

In fact, removing the own_sr check makes is_eligible unnecessary too.
Do we really need this part? Why isn't is_shrinking_candidate() enough? Tests pass without it, anyway.
Given the thread at line 228, I agree, is_shrinking_candidate() is sufficient
So this is the crux of it, yeah?
yes, pretty much. the loop happened when the first potential shard range of a new sequence was > merge_size. If it was > shrink_threshold that was ok.
this, with line 249,  is also part of the improvement i.e. sequences always get at least one member, and it's much easier to see that the index always increments.

Correct Syntax is 
Relates-To: #330

I get your reference to "Closes" with description. It can be closed along with other associated PSs. But the BOT/System reading the tag "Closes" might not interpret any other description other than looking for tag "Closes". So it is better to have only Closes for the last PSs in the series or have only Relates-To for all PSs and let user manually close it. Otherwise whenever any of the PSs with Closes tag merges, then the issue will be marked closed. That is my understanding.

zuul/executor/client.py.message:
If, somehow, the build is unpaused on the executor before this event is processed (for example, the executor is being shut down), it may be possible to clear the paused flag here immediately, and then later have the event processor set it.  I don't know if that would be a problem in practice, but...

I think we can make this simpler by just doing less.  Can we drop the paused_scheduled attribute and simply change this to:

if data.get('paused'):
  result_data = ...
  self.sched.onBuildPaused(...)

And set paused=True in onBuildPaused?

The executor sends "paused:true" only once, when the build pauses.  It isn't going to send a second "paused:true" while still paused, so I don't think we need to perform the de-duplication that having pause_scheduled provides.  I think this approach would best approximate what I think is the goal: just letting the result processor handle this work.

doc/source/reference/queue_def.rst.message: If you revise this (eg to address Simon's comment) maybe change "project" to "set of projects", just to keep it clear that this isn't something that affects single projects in isolation.

Maybe we should mention that there can be some unexpected cases with cross project gating and default/fallback branches.

E.g. when you have this option enabled and doing cross project gating and one of the projects is using a fallback branch, you have to merge the dependency first before the dependent change can enter the gate since they no longer share the same change queue.

We should mention that this can only be defined in a config-project.

However, are we sure that's what we want?  We're only going to use the first instance of a queue, so would it be harmful to allow untrusted projects to define it?  Today, if a project stanza doesn't appear in a config-project, that project can name its own queue.  We could permit the same by allowing the queue object to appear anywhere, and if an admin cares enough to specify the queue, they can do it in a config-project (thereby depriving the untrusted-project of the opportunity of specifying the queue).
I agree, I'll skip that limitation.

As I mentioned in another review, this is a glance parameter and so its name should start with Glance.

I gather glance's use of the parameter is related to it using cinder for its backend, but I find it interesting the default value '/var/lib/glance/mnt' doesn't mention cinder. I see two possible names for the THT parameter:

1. GlanceCinderMountPointBase
2. GlanceMountPointBase

I would be happy with either choice, and only ask the name does not start with "Cinder" as that would imply it's a cinder parameter.

This is not related to this change but IMO we should use parameters in puppet-tripleo to set backend parameters like cinder_store_project_name, regarding the fact we have deprecated classes for single stores like glance::backend::cinder.
Ack. I will address this in another patch.

I agree it would be cleaner if we switch all cinder/glance/manila backend parameters to use puppet-tripleo's namespace (e.g. tripleo::profile::base::glance::backend::cinder::cinder_store_password), especially because puppet-[cinder|glance|manila] backends are defined resources so hiera bindings don't apply.

That said, updating all the hiera parameters will need to be carefully orchestrated. If we undertake the task then it just needs to be done with extra care.

specs/wallaby/approved/glance/distribute.message: L:13-14, tbf this has been stable feature since Queens and always on since Rocky. Bit heavy to claim we are moving towards it now.

The "moving towards" phrasing was indicative of the Glance team's desire to see people use import as their primary method of uploading an image. I don't say anything here about it being unstable, but my interest in fixing this import problem is very specifically because I don't think it's reasonable to expect people to use this in production with a shared storage requirement. So I don't think this phrasing is unreasonable.
L:16-18 is accurate only for 'glance-direct' import method.
Again applies only on 'glance-direct' import method when the staging is it's own request.

We should not track the image data in 'extra_properties', while we do have image Locations data model already in place for this purpose. This might be fine for experimental proof of concept but should not be introduced to production code.

> Ok, lets be clear here. My objection is fundamental, not technicality. Thus I don't understand why you even thought that I would agree on the design just because someone else wrote it down when you couldn't convince me on it over the past 2 months when I owned the spec.

Okay, I have a hard time understanding how someone could be so fundamentally (but not technically) opposed to an approach that already has precedent in the tree that they would subvert a formal vote by the core team of that project. I wrote this spec because the PTL said I should, not because I thought it would change anything about the disagreement. But really, thanks for making it clear that it's not a technical objection and that there's nothing we can do to move forward here. It certainly helps me focus my energy.

How can I better acknowledge your objection to this while continuing moving forward? I think the rest of the people involved here have said that they're okay with doing this the only way we can today. I think I was pretty direct with my language here that we _will_ move to location-based metadata when an appropriate interface becomes available.

If you have specific technical reasons for why using the extra property is not suitable for production use, please articulate them and I will document them here. Given that we already use an extra property for something as important as the task lock, I think we're pretty well covered on production use of properties for internal transient purposes.

Ok, lets be clear here. My objection is fundamental, not technicality. Thus I don't understand why you even thought that I would agree on the design just because someone else wrote it down when you couldn't convince me on it over the past 2 months when I owned the spec.

We have data model for tracking the image data, our staging logic needs tweaking for us to be able to use it for this case. It does not make it any less "the only place" we should be tracking the image data. As an Example: Even we would be able to technically implement, storing the smaller images as BLOB in the database instead of using glance_store for it and we could test that it works, we would not fundamentally agree that being the right thing to do either. I am truly sorry if this did not come across clear enough after you spent all the effort polishing your proof of concept and we got stagnant on the last mile. I still think the proxy code is great and there is no way it would give me joy to see it not being released part of Wallaby.

So the intersection of "right thing to do can happen in future, not this cycle" and "can be merged when done right" seems to be "can merge in some future cycle, when done right", just like I expressed our options last week during the weekly meeting and week before that etc.

The new config options and their usage/impact should be documented together with network requirements to make this work. (Until now there has been no reason for two different glance-api nodes to be able to communicate to eachother as all requests have been coming from loadbalancers, that will not be the case anymore.)

I think I covered the deployer impact on these items in that section. I also think that config options come implicitly with some explanation. However, I'll add words here to make it clear that deployment considerations will need to be covered here, instead of sounding like the doc changes will just be subtractive of restrictions.

glance/location.py.message: AKA `if staging:`

Why do we need this staging flag, we can set_active=False while calling set_data method and also can pass this set_active at line #636

And also if we managed to do so then we could avoid passing this new parameter from entire onion layer (which means less files to review)

Well the options were that we pass indication to the set_data/upload_image_data that we're staging or we have the rest of the logic duplicated through all the layers by making it new function call. If we were looking just set_active flag, when ever we did image import we would be "staging" all but the last image as we default to set_active=False due to the all_stores_must_succeed defaulting True. As the set_active is kwarg, we can literally call image.set_data(payload, staging=True) we do not need to pass any of the other parameters and we still get the correct result, also as long as staging is not passed or passed as staging=False the functionality works exactly as before and we don't need to refactor any of the logic relying on that.

Agree with Abhi, this too is much too much linkage between layers that should be independent. If we are creating a location in the staging store, we should provide set_active=False here. Why do we need a new special case flag?
also we need to avoid setting virtual size during staging operation.

Vitrual size should not be a problem. Even after the conversion the virtual size will be the same, only thing that changes is the actual image size. We can put check for it there if preferred, I just didn't see need for it as it won't change the end result.

I don't think you can say that it doesn't matter. Some image formats (I'm thinking HDX) have minimum (or default) extent sizes, so that if you upload an image that is not an equal number of extents, the conversion process will have to inflate it to the next size up.

However, this is another good example of my general concern that treating the staging area as a store brings a bunch of special cases that negate (or at least erode) the supposed gains we get from it. Right now, we barely use it as a store, but fleshing out its usage in this patch uncovers all of these places where we have to do special handling. I think that's concerning.

Now we need to document it somewhere that if we are using single store configuration then we must have to define 'file' store compulsory in `stores` option under glance_store section even if we are not using it.

Otherwise it will fail with 500 error at line #540 with error;
glance_store.exceptions.UnknownScheme: Unknown scheme 'file' found in URI

Note:
This is not a regression of this patch, this is pre-existing bug.
To fix this we need to catch above error and raise BadRequest to user
Same deal here: I think that if the API user creates the only location for this image directly, and happens to be using "staging_host" in metadata, you will avoid setting the image size here.
addressed in PS5 by avoiding the usage of 'metadata'

But it doesn't shrink much in that you're planning to keep this "if staging" special case here right?

As I mentioned before, this method is now over a hundred lines long and far too complex, IMHO. It is at least four pieces, existing in two hemispheres (i.e. "what we normally do" and "what we do if this is the special staging case"). It effectively bakes a bunch of high-level logic into a very low-level routine, which I think is a serious anti-pattern. However, if we're going to design it that way, it really needs to be broken into pieces so it's more readable.
it really does, I did some dedup there for PS5 and really the non-multi-store config is what causes lots of the code duplication here.

IMHO, if using the glance store driver for the staging area is really the right way to manage it (instead of just assuming it's a filesystem directory and foregoing all of the layers on top), then we shouldn't need low-level hacks like this. The existing special-casing we already have everywhere to "treat it like a store, but just grab the path and diddle the filesystem directly anyway" is what makes me skeptical that it's the right approach. Flags like this passed through all the layers really cement that concern.
ditto
This is enormously hacky and mutating config is definitely not something we should be doing at runtime, IMHO. Definitely not with every image stage.
Exactly and this is something we have duplicated all over the place currently and stays that way with your original proposal.

Just as a preview for when this is actually a URL, as described in the comment, let me say:

As I said before, this is, IMHO, a layering violation. Having the low-level storage layer setting things that are the business of the API directly is a bad design and links those two things with special behavior. The API will need to look at this and compare it to its copy of the value to know what to do anyway. Putting it here just means the low-level location-storing code is subtly linked to the high-level API code.
Echoing my concern in the latest patch set about this layering violation and brings a bunch of change to "the onion" that is both unnecessary and not desirable.

I just express my humble disagreement here. Having the locations metadata recorded where the location is created is way less violating than storing that information with the characteristics of the image and hoping that someone remembers to pick it up from there.

yes for both, and deserves cleanup. Good candidate for follow up, right ;)
Again, using this as a boolean :)

glance/location.py.message: How does it make it simpler? In my version, we compare staging_host to our copy of either of those, and if different, we proxy. With this, you now have this magic string, which someone *could* set in the config and then end up very confused. Instead of getting an "unable to connect to not_set" and realizing their error, they'd see nothing.

As noted elsewhere, I think setting this deep in the location code, according to this special-case staging flag, is a layering violation. This URL is the business of the API, and it has to do all the comparisons, so setting it should *also* be done there.
yup like said this likely deserves following cleanup.

glance/db/sqlalchemy/alembic_migrations/.message: Not seeing any benefits for this specific column

But it doesn't seem like you're really using it? Or at least not consistently.

Having a boolean and the host URL also gives us the potential for them to get out of sync somehow. If you can use the URL as a boolean, why would you not want to have one source of truth instead of two?

Makes lots of he logic cleaner and easy to flag the staing location without exposing the staging_host details. Specially as we do not have hard requirement to have anything meaningful to put into the staging_host. Just made the life in general easier with next to no cost.
I don't understand how it can make things easier, especially when staging_host is nullable. Using it as a boolean should already work, so I'm not sure why we need this.

Like I discussed with Abhishek, for the cost of 1 bit we simplify the logic a lot (specially _if_ we decide not wanting to utilize the "not_set" for the cases where we would be setting it null.) We would need to implement this as pseudo parameter of the location at the API level (and test all possible corner cases of it) while now we can just remove the staging_host and still flag the location being staging directly from the data model and lock it with schema.

As I argued in the spec, I do not understand why it makes sense to reserve space in the database for the life of an image, for a piece of information we only need (a) if we're doing import for that image and (b) for a short period of time in the overall scheme of things. This is multiplied by not only all the images in the DB, but by all the locations on those images. The "benefit" of using location metadata was that we already have to reserve that space anyway (although granted it brought a lot of problems on its own).
IIUC Null + Null is still Null and False + Null is 1 bit. So I don't think it's exactly a massive increase in our data model to have these 2 columns here.

Clearly, nobody is going to run out of disk space because of the waste here, that's for sure. However, everything we have here in our data model is both long-term cognitive load on the developers and reviewers in terms of making sure it's properly used and handled, but also machine load in terms of the work we do both in SQL and in python to address these columns when we read and write to this table. It's potentially operator/upgrade load, in that we have to expand their database now (which is measurable) or later if we change this mechanism, we have to transition their schema, potentially migrate data, etc. For something that will be completely empty at all times of steady state, it's 100% waste to continually load, handle, compare, and save that field for all image (locations). All that stuff builds up over time, contributing to the already high CPU load, memory footprint, and upgrade time of a lot of openstack projects. Cleaning it up requires a large number of small tweaks.
